citations.narrative:
There are a number of items unrelated to the husbandry of the dogs stored in the shelter structure where one of the
livestock guardian dogs (Mufasa) is housed and is allowed to roam. This includes loose bolts, pieces of wire, empty
bleach bottles, and various other maintenance items. Allowing dogs to have access to these items can lead to injury or
inappropriate ingestion. The licensee must ensure that housing facilities and areas used for storing animal food or
bedding must be free of any accumulation of trash, waste material, junk, weeds, and other discarded materials. Animal
areas inside of housing facilities must be kept neat and free of clutter, including equipment, furniture, and stored material,
but may contain materials actually used and necessary for cleaning the area, and fixtures or equipment necessary for
proper husbandry practices and research needs. Correct by June 23, 2023.

One enclosure failed to protect the animals from injury. On May 18, 2023, 4 goats were killed overnight and many of the
remaining goats in the herd were wounded by stray dogs that gained access to the area through breaks in the outer
perimeter fence and dug under the pasture fence and entered the enclosure housing the goats. Since the incident, the
licensee has moved the goats to an area with additional electric fencing and has implemented the use of a livestock
guardian dog. Animal enclosures that do not adequately protect them from escape, injury, or predators may suffer from
stress, injury, or death. Correct by ensuring that all animal enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in good
repair to contain the animals and protect the animals from injury. Corrected at the time of the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian and facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.1(b) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There are a number of items unrelated to the husbandry of the dogs stored in the shelter structure where one of the 
livestock guardian dogs (Mufasa) is housed and is allowed to roam. This includes loose bolts, pieces of wire, empty 
bleach bottles, and various other maintenance items. Allowing dogs to have access to these items can lead to injury or 
inappropriate ingestion. The licensee must ensure that housing facilities and areas used for storing animal food or 
bedding must be free of any accumulation of trash, waste material, junk, weeds, and other discarded materials. Animal 
areas inside of housing facilities must be kept neat and free of clutter, including equipment, furniture, and stored material, 
but may contain materials actually used and necessary for cleaning the area, and fixtures or equipment necessary for 
proper husbandry practices and research needs. Correct by June 23, 2023. 
3.125(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
One enclosure failed to protect the animals from injury. On May 18, 2023, 4 goats were killed overnight and many of the 
remaining goats in the herd were wounded by stray dogs that gained access to the area through breaks in the outer 
perimeter fence and dug under the pasture fence and entered the enclosure housing the goats. Since the incident, the 
licensee has moved the goats to an area with additional electric fencing and has implemented the use of a livestock 
guardian dog. Animal enclosures that do not adequately protect them from escape, injury, or predators may suffer from 
stress, injury, or death. Correct by ensuring that all animal enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in good 
repair to contain the animals and protect the animals from injury. Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian and facility representatives.
